title: Data Collection and Analysis for the Cognitive Neurosciences (PSMCV-2)
text:
Link to Schedule


PSMCV-2: Data Collection and Analysis for Cognitive Neuroscience, 2025-2026-1a
Second updated version, 25. October 2024

Coordinator: Mark Span (m.m.span@rug.nl)]
Instructors: Mark Span; Olaf Dimigen
Guest lecturers: Sebastiaan Mathôt, Ana Vilotijeviç



In this course, you will learn how to design, program, and conduct a psychophysical experiment; and you will learn how to analyse the data sets. Students will participate in a pupil dilation experiment of which the data will be analysed in class. Techniques required to analyse this type of data (e.g., processing of markers and selection of analysis windows) are learned. For this, the programming language “Python” will be used. Students will, in groups, build their own pupil dilation experiment using “OpenSesame” and will collect data. Assessment will consist of assignments, and the report written about the experiment and data analysis. The report will take the form of a short journal paper, and a more extensive report of the data analyses.
After taking this hands-on course, students:

are able to design and implement a psychophysiological experiment in which pupil dilation and eye movements are recorded
can use tools to analyse and present data collected in such experiments. 




The first goal of the course is to explore literature for a pupillometry study that you find interesting. You will aim to replicate the experimental findings of this study: either an exact replication or a replication with a small adaptation to the design (e.g., change stimulus modality). In the ideal scenario, you will collect and analyse your own data in week 40 upto 43 (see Course Outline below).
You will work together in groups that you form in the first meetings. Although you will work in groups, you are expected to submit the assignments individually (except for Assignment 1 and 5).
This is a “hands-on” course and therefore most of our meetings take the form of a practicum. The required theoretical knowledge for the practicums is discussed in the form of lectures. Generally, our Wednesday meetings will be theoretically oriented and our Friday meetings practically oriented. Below the course planning is outlined:


Course Outline

(*) Lab M226 is blocked for you from Monday 30.9. to Monday 14.10 of October, all day.


Due dates for assignments 







Due date
Task
Grading




11 Sep - 09:00
Assignment 0: Submit (written) experimental proposal
No grade; individual submission is required


23 Sep - 09:00
Assignment 1: Upload experiment
Graded as group assignment


11 Oct - 09:00
Assignment 3: Preprocessing assignment
Graded as individual assignment


14 Oct - 09:00
Assignment 4: Analyses assignment
Graded as individual assignment


25 Oct
Assignment 5: Presentation
Graded as group assignment



Assignment 6: Peer review
No grade; submission is required


29 Oct, 18:00
Send out draft for peer review



1 Nov, 18:00
Return peer review by Oct



11 Nov
Final Paper
Graded as individual assignment






Assignments 3, 4 and 5 will be graded 0 - 4. The final paper will be graded 1 - 10. The final grade for the course is calculated as follows:
Final grade = 0.2 * mean(Assignments * 2.5) + (0.8 * paper).
Students will only receive a final grade upon submission of all assignments.



The final paper consists of: 

“Abstract” containing main points from introduction and discussion (max. 180 words)
Methods & Results (also mention if or where your analysis deviated from your pre-registration

library(ggplot2)

ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
  stat_density_2d(aes(fill = ..level..), geom = "polygon", color = "white") +
  scale_fill_viridis_c() + 
  labs(title = "Data Collection Course",
       x = "Olaf",
       y = "Mark",
       fill = "Knowledge") +
  theme_minimal()

Warning: The dot-dot notation (`..level..`) was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
